prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context:
In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent people and remain consistent across layers. The weighted connections between nodes indicate social contacts that could potentially lead to infection based on the edge weight, a probability value ranging from 0 to 1.

The first layer of the network depicts home interactions and consists of groups of varying sizes. These groups are internally fully connected but have no external connections, essentially starting as disconnected components representing individual families. The size distribution of families is based on data from Colombia in 2009, taking into account family sizes ranging from 1 to 14 members and considering the probability of families having sizes from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of any country's population engages in some form of economic activity, requiring interaction with others. Work plays a crucial role in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To represent this, we propose a layer to connect individuals aged 18 to 59, encompassing 60% of Colombia's population. Given the diverse job market, establishing connection rules reflecting real-world dynamics is challenging. We consider a scenario with random groups of sizes between 5 and 30, internally connected like the ''home'' layer. An illustration is shown in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The spread of the virus within a group depends on edge weights, detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in most cities but poses a risk for epidemic spread due to high population density. Our third layer represents public transport users, estimated at 50%, forming randomly sized groups between 10 and 40. Each group is fully connected, reflecting the average daily use of 1.2 hours.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In the article by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021), Fig. 2 illustrates each social layer of a proposed multi-layer network. In this network, nodes represent people and weighted connections signify social contacts that could lead to infection based on probability values between 0 and 1. The first layer focuses on home interactions, consisting of groups of various sizes that are internally connected but isolated from other groups, simulating family units. The distribution of family sizes in Argentina from 2010 is used to create these groups, ensuring at least one adult in each family. Additionally, a generic layer is introduced to represent work interactions, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59 years, which accounts for 60% of Argentina's population. This layer aims to capture the significant impact of work activities on social relations and potential epidemics.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .The interconnected nodes within a group are integral in the spread of the virus, with the specific factors discussed in depth in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation systems are crucial in urban areas, serving as potential hotspots for disease transmission due to the constant movement of vehicles. Our proposed third layer focuses on these collective transports, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of public transport users varies by city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging around 1.2 hours of use per day. For our analysis, we consider a 50% participation rate from a randomly sampled population for the ''transports'' layer, where groups of varying sizes between 10 and 40 individuals are interconnected. Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-argentina/noticia/2015/02/argentinos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html.

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers examined the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including increases and decreases in cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The study used a social network model with original infection probabilities, starting from a node with the closest degree to the network average. The infection spread was simulated over 300 days, with daily iterations, under an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: .The activities that continue on despite quarantine restrictions include essential services and those that are taking extra precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. In this situation, we examine how the β parameter influences the shape of the epidemic. Results from different β values are shown in Fig. 4(a), demonstrating that higher infection rates lead to faster disease transmission and more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity in recovered individuals. When comparing our model's output to real data from the Brazilian epidemic, we find that a β value of 0.3 aligns better with the actual situation, where people are wearing masks and being cautious. The model generally matches the data well, with some discrepancies possibly due to increased testing and fluctuating levels of isolation. As for daily death tolls, the model's average numbers are slightly higher than official figures, likely due to underdetection and limited testing. This suggests that the true number of cases and deaths may be higher than reported.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
The study by eiva et al. (2021) in Physica A 564 explores the impact of various measures on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation begins with a social network with all layers and original infection probabilities. Infection starts at a node with a degree close to the average network degree and spreads over 300 days. An optimistic scenario is considered, where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, leading to a lower initial infection probability of β < 1. This reflects natural social distancing and precautions to prevent transmission. A moderate quarantine is implemented after 27 days, reducing certain activities and contacts to 30% of their initial levels (β = 0.09). Results demonstrate that this parameter has a significant impact on the epidemic curve, affecting daily cases and deaths. Higher infection rates lead to faster spread but also quicker resolution due to natural immunity.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 17) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using

author: enrique
pre_context: Scabini, Ribas, and M.B. L.F.S.Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 (a) Analysis of different β values and their impacts on the shape of new cases and deaths. (b) Comparison between the proposed model best Fig. 4. fit (
post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 24) to 4 different data sources of the Argentinian COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42]. The standard deviation is represented by the dotted lines, with the curve showing the average over a 5-day period for real data and solid lines indicating the raw data. The high number of deaths from the proposed model may be due to underdetection, as shown in Fig. 5. In order to analyze the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Argentina, we compared official death records from 2019 and 2020 during the same period (January 1 to April 30) [44]. This difference was then compared to COVID-19 records from the WHO [42] and Argentinian government data [44]. The significant discrepancy seen after the first confirmed case suggests a notable underdetection of COVID-19 cases. By resuming all activities and factoring in growth, peak, and decline times, the projected total number of diagnosed cases is 1,253,119 (± 26,009) and deaths 197,756 (± 5,693). Implementing a strict 90-day lockdown leads to a substantial decrease in infection and death rates compared to other strategies. Recovery time is also quicker, with new cases peaking on day 93 (June 1) and new deaths on day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there are 552,855 (± 195,802) diagnosed cases and 87,059 (± 30,871) deaths. By estimating hospitalization needs for both severe and critical cases based on Fig. 3, the difference between diagnosed and undiagnosed cases can be seen along with the number of recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers including L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, and M.B. Neiva analyzed three possible scenarios after 90 days following different levels of isolation due to the COVID-19 pandemic. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or increasing isolation by stopping work and public transport. The study found that testing limitations, such as the low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus, hinder accurate diagnosis, with only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases being identified. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days from the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were implemented which included the closure of schools and religious activities, while work and transports continued at 30% of normal capacity. Various options were considered after 90 days from the first case: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation and returning to full activity, or only returning work activities. Results showed that maintaining current isolation levels would lead to a prolonged outbreak, with an estimated peak around June 5 resulting in an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths may occur. Hospitals may exceed capacity around June 11, but with efficient implementation of new ICU beds and proper logistics, the situation could be managed. However, this optimistic scenario relies on maintaining social isolation levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Colombian quarantine. Currently, Colombia's social isolation levels are consistently around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days from May 26. These scenarios include maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures by stopping work and public transport. Testing for the virus is limited due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus, resulting in only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and continue to interact normally in the community. It is assumed that mild cases, even if undiagnosed, are aware of their symptoms and isolate themselves at home, while severe and critical cases are hospitalized and fully isolated from the community network.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context: , and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.Hospitals could reach maximum capacity around June 11 in this situation, but by efficiently adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation can still be controlled. However, this assumption is quite optimistic, as it is based on maintaining social isolation at over 50%, as seen at the start of the Colombian quarantine. Colombia's current social isolation levels are consistently at 12.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A in 2021, researchers examined the impact of different scenarios on the spread of infections after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing limitations, such as the low number of tests or the rapid spread of infection, impacted the ability to accurately diagnose cases. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were assumed to be diagnosed in the model, with asymptomatic cases not being diagnosed. The study also assumed that mild cases would self-isolate at home if aware of their symptoms, while severe and critical cases would be hospitalized and isolated from the network.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of
post_context: and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.In this situation, hospitals could reach full capacity by June 11. Nevertheless, if new ICU beds are promptly set up and patients are managed efficiently, the situation may still be manageable. However, this outlook is quite optimistic, as it relies on the assumption that maintaining isolation at over 50%, as seen at the start of the quarantine in Argentina, will continue. Current social isolation levels in Argentina remain at a steady 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A in 2021, researchers analyzed three possible scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation, or increasing isolation. Testing limitations were acknowledged due to the low number of tests available or the rapid spread of the virus. It was assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread in the network. The study also assumed that mild cases would self-isolate at home, while severe cases would be hospitalized and isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of
post_context: (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. In this situation, hospitals could reach their maximum capacity by June 11. However, by efficiently adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation may still be manageable. This is a somewhat optimistic outlook, as it assumes that social isolation rates will remain above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentinian quarantine [43]. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels are at a consistent 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A, researchers examined three potential scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, lifting isolation restrictions, or increasing isolation measures. The study found that testing limitations, such as a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus, made it difficult to accurately diagnose cases. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were assumed to be diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases were not identified. The researchers also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals self-isolating at home if they had mild symptoms, while severe and critical cases were assumed to be hospitalized and effectively removed from the transmission network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year. By June 11, hospitals may reach their maximum capacity in this situation. But if new ICU beds are promptly put in place, and patients are managed efficiently, the situation can still be managed. However, this assumption is quite optimistic, as our definition of "keeping isolation" requires a social isolation rate of over 50%, which was seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine. Argentina's social isolation levels have consistently remained at 12%.
